statement: A5. Distinguish Z from -Ztime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an operation that implements a single-qubit unitary transformation: either the Z gate or the -Z gate (i.e., the $$$-|0\\rangle\\langle0| + |1\\rangle\\langle1|$$$ gate: $$$(-Z)(\\alpha|0\\rangle + \\beta|1\\rangle) = -\\alpha|0\\rangle + \\beta|1\\rangle$$$). The operation will have Adjoint and Controlled variants defined.Your task is to perform necessary operations and measurements to figure out which unitary it was and to return 0 if it was the Z gate or 1 if it was the -Z gate.You are allowed to apply the given operation and its adjoint/controlled variants exactlyonce.You have to implement an operation which takes a single-qubit operation as an input and returns an integer. processed.result:
You are given a quantum operation that acts on a single qubit. This operation can be either the Z gate or the -Z gate. The Z gate is defined as:

$$Z |0\rangle = |0\rangle$$
$$Z |1\rangle = -|1\rangle$$

The -Z gate is defined as:

$$-Z |0\rangle = |0\rangle$$
$$-Z |1\rangle = |1\rangle$$

You are allowed to apply this operation, its adjoint (reverse), and its controlled version (which applies the operation only if a second qubit is in the state $|1\rangle$) exactly once.

Your task is to figure out whether the operation was the Z gate or the -Z gate. You can do this by performing measurements on the qubit.

You need to write a program that takes the quantum operation as input and outputs 0 if it was the Z gate and 1 if it was the -Z gate.

You are given a function that performs one of two operations on a single bit. You can apply this function, its inverse, or a controlled version of it only once. Your goal is to determine which of the two original functions was used.
